message_1: Using second-order logic, determine the number of ways to choose four different integers from the set {1, 2, 3, ..., 10} without selecting any two consecutive integers in the same choice.
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the concept of combinatorics. We will first find the total number of ways to choose four different integers from the set {1, 2, 3, ..., 10} and then subtract the number of ways in which two consecutive integers are chosen.

The total number of ways to choose four different integers from the set {1, 2, 3, ..., 10} is given by the combination formula:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

In this case, n = 10 (the number of elements in the set) and k = 4 (the number of integers we want to choose).

C(10, 4) = 10! / (4!(10-4)!) = 10! / (4!6!) = 210

Now, we need to find the number of ways in which two consecutive integers are chosen. We can do this by considering the number of ways to choose three non-consecutive integers from the set {1, 2, 3, ..., 8} and then adding one to each of these integers. This will give us a set of four integers with two consecutive integers.

The number of ways to choose three non-consecutive integers from the set {1, 2, 3, ..., 8} is given by:

C(8, 3) = 8! / (3!(8-3)!) = 8! / (3!5!) = 56

So, the number of ways to choose four different integers from the set {1, 2, 3, ..., 10} without selecting any two consecutive integers in the same choice is:

210 - 56 = 154

Therefore, there are 154 ways to choose four different integers from the set {1, 2, 3, ..., 10} without selecting any two consecutive integers in the same choice.
